standard_metadata.standard_description: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

hints.content: To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $3$ that may be useful:  - $3 \times 3 = 9$ - $3 \times 5 = 15$ - $3 \times 9 = 27$
What multiple of $3$ is less than $417$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {3}&\overline{\Big)417} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $417$ into $\purpleD{100}$ threes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{3}&\overline{\Big)417}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{300}}&\purpleD{100}&\maroonD{3} \times \purpleD{100} = \blueE{300}\\ &117 \end{array}$  We have $117$ left.

Let's divide $117$ into $\purpleD{30}$ more threes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{3}&\overline{\Big)417}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{300}&100\\ &117\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{90}}&\purpleD{30}&\maroonD{3} \times \purpleD{30} = \blueE{90}\\ &27\\ \end{array}$  We have $27$ left.

Let's divide $27$ into $\purpleD{9}$ more threes since  $9 \times 3=27$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{3}&\overline{\Big)417}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{300}&100\\ &117\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{90}&30\\ &27\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{27}}&\purpleD{9}&\maroonD{3} \times \purpleD{9} = \blueE{27}\\ &0 \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {3}&\overline{\Big)417}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{300}&\purpleD{100}\\ &117\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{90}&\purpleD{30}\\ &27\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{27}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{9}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{139} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{100} + \purpleD{30} + \purpleD{9}= \greenE{139}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$417\div3=\greenE{139}$ remainder $\goldE{0}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $4$ that may be useful:  - $4 \times 2 = 8$ - $4 \times 5 = 20$ - $4 \times 8 = 32$
What multiple of $4$ is less than $6{,}352$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {4}&\overline{\Big)6{,}352} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $6{,}352$ into $\purpleD{1{,}000}$ fours.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{4}&\overline{\Big)6{,}352}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{4{,}000}}&\purpleD{1{,}000}&\maroonD{4} \times \purpleD{1{,}000} = \blueE{4{,}000}\\ &2{,}352 \end{array}$  We have $2{,}352$ left.

Let's divide $2{,}352$ into $\purpleD{500}$ more fours.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{4}&\overline{\Big)6{,}352}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{4{,}000}&1{,}000\\ &2{,}352\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{2{,}000}}&\purpleD{500}&\maroonD{4} \times \purpleD{500} = \blueE{2{,}000}\\ &352 \end{array}$  We have $352$ left.

Let's divide $352$ into $\purpleD{80}$ more fours.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{4}&\overline{\Big)6{,}352}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{4{,}000}&1{,}000\\ &2{,}352\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}000}&500\\ &352\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{320}}&\purpleD{80}&\maroonD{4} \times \purpleD{80} = \blueE{320}\\ &32 \end{array}$  We have $32$ left.

Let's divide $32$ into $\purpleD{8}$ more fours since  $8 \times 4=32$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{4}&\overline{\Big)6{,}352}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{4{,}000}&1{,}000\\ &2{,}352\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}000}&500\\ &352\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{320}&80\\ &32\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{32}}&\purpleD{8}&\maroonD{4} \times \purpleD{8} = \blueE{32}\\ &0 \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {4}&\overline{\Big)6{,}352}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{4{,}000}&\purpleD{1{,}000}\\ &2{,}352\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}000}&\purpleD{500}\\ &352\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{320}&\purpleD{80}\\ &32\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{32}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{8}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{1{,}588}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{1000} + \purpleD{500} + \purpleD{80} + \purpleD{8}= \greenE{1{,}588}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$6{,}352\div4=\greenE{1{,}588}$ remainder $\goldE{0}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $2$ that may be useful:  - $2 \times 4 = 8$ - $2 \times 5 = 10$ - $2 \times 25 = 50$
What multiple of $2$ is less than $952$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {2}&\overline{\Big)952}\\ \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $952$ into $\purpleD{400}$ twos.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{2}&\overline{\Big)952}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{800}}&\purpleD{400}&\maroonD{2} \times \purpleD{400} = \blueE{800}\\ &152 \end{array}$  We have $152$ left.

Let's divide $152$ into $\purpleD{50}$ more twos.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{2}&\overline{\Big)952}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{800}&400\\ &152\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{100}}&\purpleD{50}&\maroonD{2} \times \purpleD{50} = \blueE{100}\\ &52 \end{array}$  We have $52$ left.

Let's divide $52$ into $\purpleD{25}$ more twos.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{2}&\overline{\Big)952}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{800}&400\\ &152\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{100}&50\\ &52\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{50}}&\purpleD{25}&\maroonD{2} \times \purpleD{25} = \blueE{50}\\ &2 \end{array}$  We have $2$ left.

Let's divide $2$ into $\purpleD{1}$ last two.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{2}&\overline{\Big)952}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{800}&400\\ &152\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{100}&50\\ &52\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{50}&25\\ &2\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{2}}&\purpleD{1}&\maroonD{2} \times \purpleD{1} = \blueE{2}\\ &0 \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {2}&\overline{\Big)952}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{800}&\purpleD{400}\\ &152\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{100}&\purpleD{50}\\ &52\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{50}&\purpleD{25}\\ &2\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{1}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{476} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{400} + \purpleD{50} + \purpleD{25} + \purpleD{1}= \greenE{476}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{476}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{0}\\ 2\overline{\Big)952}& \end{align}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $5$ that may be useful:  - $5 \times 4 = 20$ - $5 \times 5 = 25$ - $5 \times 7 = 35$
What multiple of $5$ is less than $2{,}235$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {5}&\overline{\Big)2{,}235} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $2{,}235$ into $\purpleD{400}$ fives.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{5}&\overline{\Big)2{,}235}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{2{,}000}}&\purpleD{400}&\maroonD{5} \times \purpleD{400} = \blueE{2{,}000}\\ &235 \end{array}$  We have $235$ left.

Let's divide $235$ into $\purpleD{40}$ more fives.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{5}&\overline{\Big)2{,}235}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}000}&400\\ &235\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{200}}&\purpleD{40}&\maroonD{5} \times \purpleD{40} = \blueE{200}\\ &35 \end{array}$  We have $35$ left.

Let's divide $35$ into $\purpleD{7}$ more fives since  $7 \times 5=35$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{5}&\overline{\Big)2{,}235}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}000}&400\\ &235\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{200}&40\\ &35\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{35}}&\purpleD{7}&\maroonD{5} \times \purpleD{7} = \blueE{35}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {5}&\overline{\Big)2{,}235}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}000}&\purpleD{400}\\ &235\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{200}&\purpleD{40}\\ &35\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{35}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{7}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{447} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{400} + \purpleD{40} + \purpleD{7}= \greenE{447}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{447}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{0}\\ 5\overline{\Big)2{,}235}& \end{align}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $2$ that may be useful:  - $2 \times 10 = 20$ - $2 \times 2 = 4$ - $2 \times 5 = 10$
What multiple of $2$ is less than $430$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {2}&\overline{\Big)430}\\ \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $430$ into $\purpleD{200}$ twos.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{2}&\overline{\Big)430}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{400}}&\purpleD{200}&\maroonD{2} \times \purpleD{200} = \blueE{400}\\ &30\\ \end{array}$  We have $30$ left.

Let's divide $30$ into $\purpleD{10}$ more twos.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{2}&\overline{\Big)430}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{400}&200\\ &30\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{20}}&\purpleD{10}&\maroonD{2} \times \purpleD{10} = \blueE{20}\\ &10\\ \end{array}$  We have $10$ left.

Let's divide $10$ into $\purpleD{5}$ more twos since  $2 \times 5=10$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{2}&\overline{\Big)430}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{400}&200\\ &30\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{20}&10\\ &10\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{10}}&\purpleD{5}&\maroonD{2} \times \purpleD{5} = \blueE{10}\\ &0\\ \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {2}&\overline{\Big)430}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{400}&\purpleD{200}\\ &30\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{20}&\purpleD{10}\\ &10\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{10}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{5}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{215}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{200} + \purpleD{10} + \purpleD{5}= \greenE{215}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$430\div2 = \greenE{215}$ remainder $\goldE{0}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $4$ that may be useful:  - $4 \times 25 = 100$ - $4 \times 2 = 8$ - $4 \times 10 = 40$
What multiple of $4$ is less than $5{,}007$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {4}&\overline{\Big)5{,}007}\\ \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $5{,}007$ into $\purpleD{1{,}000}$ fours.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{4}&\overline{\Big)5{,}007}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{4{,}000}}&\purpleD{1{,}000}&\maroonD{4} \times \purpleD{1{,}000} = \blueE{4{,}000}\\ &1{,}007\\ \end{array}$  We have $1{,}007$ left.

Let's divide $1{,}007$ into $\purpleD{250}$ more fours.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{4}&\overline{\Big)5{,}007}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{4{,}000}&1{,}000\\ &1{,}007\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{1{,}000}}&\purpleD{250}&\maroonD{4} \times \purpleD{250} = \blueE{1{,}000}\\ &7\\ \end{array}$  We have $7$ left.

Let's divide $7$ into $\purpleD{1}$ last four.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{4}&\overline{\Big)5{,}007}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{4{,}000}&1{,}000\\ &1{,}007\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{1{,}000}&250\\ &7\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{4}}&\purpleD{1}&\maroonD{4} \times \purpleD{1} = \blueE{4}\\ &3\\ \end{array}$  We have $3$ left. That is less than $4$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {4}&\overline{\Big)5{,}007}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{4{,}000}&\purpleD{1{,}000}\\ &1{,}007\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{1{,}000}&\purpleD{250}\\ &7\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{4}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{1}}\\ &\goldE{3}&\greenE{1{,}251}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{1{,}000} + \purpleD{250} + \purpleD{1}= \greenE{1{,}251}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{3}$.
$5{,}007\div 4 = \greenE{1{,}251}$ remainder $\goldE{3}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $5$ that may be useful:  - $5 \times 2 = 10$ - $5 \times 5 = 25$ - $5 \times 6 = 30$
What multiple of $5$ is less than $320$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {5}&\overline{\Big)320} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $320$ into $\purpleD{60}$ fives.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{5}&\overline{\Big)320}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{300}}&\purpleD{60}&\maroonD{5} \times \purpleD{60} = \blueE{300}\\ &20 \end{array}$  We have $20$ left.

Let's divide $20$ into $\purpleD{4}$ more fives since  $4 \times 5=20$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{5}&\overline{\Big)320}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{300}&60\\ &20\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{20}}&\purpleD{4}&\maroonD{5} \times \purpleD{4} = \blueE{20}\\ &0 \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {5}&\overline{\Big)320}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{300}&\purpleD{60}\\ &20\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{20}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{4}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{64} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{60} + \purpleD{4}= \greenE{64}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{64}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{0}\\ 5\overline{\Big)320}& \end{align}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $3$ that may be useful:  - $3 \times 2 = 6$ - $3 \times 3 = 9$ - $3 \times 6 = 18$
What multiple of $3$ is less than $1{,}090$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {3}&\overline{\Big)1{,}090} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $1{,}090$ into $\purpleD{300}$ threes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{3}&\overline{\Big)1{,}090}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{900}}&\purpleD{300}&\maroonD{3} \times \purpleD{300} = \blueE{900}\\ &190 \end{array}$  We have $190$ left.

Let's divide $190$ into $\purpleD{60}$ more threes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{3}&\overline{\Big)1{,}090}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{900}&300\\ &190\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{180}}&\purpleD{60}&\maroonD{3} \times \purpleD{60} = \blueE{180}\\ &10 \end{array}$  We have $10$ left.

Let's divide $10$ into $\purpleD{3}$ more threes since $3\times 3=9$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{3}&\overline{\Big)1{,}090}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{900}&300\\ &190\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{180}&60\\ &10\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{9}}&\purpleD{3}&\maroonD{3} \times \purpleD{3} = \blueE{9}\\ &1 \end{array}$  We have $1$ left. That is less than $3$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {3}&\overline{\Big)1{,}090}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{900}&\purpleD{300}\\ &190\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{180}&\purpleD{60}\\ &10\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{9}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{3}}\\ &\goldE{1}&\greenE{363} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{300} + \purpleD{60} + \purpleD{3}= \greenE{363}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{1}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{363}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{1}\\ 3\overline{\Big)1{,}090}& \end{align}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $3$ that may be useful:  - $3 \times 2 = 6$ - $3 \times 7 = 21$ - $3 \times 9 = 27$
What multiple of $3$ is less than $2{,}721$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {3}&\overline{\Big)2{,}721} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $2{,}721$ into $\purpleD{900}$ threes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{3}&\overline{\Big)2{,}721}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{2{,}700}}&\purpleD{900}&\maroonD{3} \times \purpleD{900} = \blueE{2{,}700}\\ &21 \end{array}$  We have $21$ left.

Let's divide $21$ into $\purpleD{7}$ more threes since  $7 \times 3=21$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{3}&\overline{\Big)2{,}721}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}700}&900\\ &21\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{21}}&\purpleD{7}&\maroonD{3} \times \purpleD{7} = \blueE{21}\\ &0 \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {3}&\overline{\Big)2{,}721}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}700}&\purpleD{900}\\ &21\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{21}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{7}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{907} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{900} + \purpleD{7}= \greenE{907}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$2{,}721\div3=\greenE{907}$ remainder $\goldE{0}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $2$ that may be useful:  - $2 \times 2 = 4$ - $2 \times 5 = 10$ - $2 \times 6 = 12$
What multiple of $2$ is less than $413$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {2}&\overline{\Big)413} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $413$ into $\purpleD{200}$ twos.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{2}&\overline{\Big)413}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{400}}&\purpleD{200}&\maroonD{2} \times \purpleD{200} = \blueE{400}\\ &13\\ \end{array}$  We have $13$ left.

Let's divide $13$ into $\purpleD{6}$ more twos.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{2}&\overline{\Big)413}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{400}&200\\ &13\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{12}}&\purpleD{6}&\maroonD{2} \times \purpleD{6} = \blueE{12}\\ &1 \end{array}$  We have $1$ left. That is less than $2$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {2}&\overline{\Big)413}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{400}&\purpleD{200}\\ &13\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{12}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{6}}\\ &\goldE{1}&\greenE{206} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{200} + \purpleD{6}= \greenE{206}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{1}$.
$413\div2=\greenE{206}$ remainder $\goldE{1}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $4$ that may be useful:  - $4 \times 2 = 8$ - $4 \times 5 = 20$ - $4 \times 7 = 28$
What multiple of $4$ is less than $828$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {4}&\overline{\Big)828}\\ \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $828$ into $\purpleD{200}$ fours.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{4}&\overline{\Big)828}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{800}}&\purpleD{200}&\maroonD{4} \times \purpleD{200} = \blueE{800}\\ &28\\ \end{array}$  We have $28$ left.

Let's divide $28$ into $\purpleD{7}$ more fours since  $7 \times 4=28$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{4}&\overline{\Big)828}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{800}&200\\ &28\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{28}}&\purpleD{7}&\maroonD{4} \times \purpleD{7} = \blueE{28}\\ &0 \end{array}$

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {4}&\overline{\Big)828}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{800}&\purpleD{200}\\ &28\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{28}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{7}}\\ &\goldE{0}&\greenE{207} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{200} + \purpleD{7}= \greenE{207}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{0}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{207}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{0}\\ 4\overline{\Big)828}& \end{align}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $5$ that may be useful:  - $5 \times 8 = 40$ - $5 \times 9 = 45$ - $5 \times 10 = 50$
What multiple of $5$ is less than $4{,}454$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {5}&\overline{\Big)4{,}454} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $4{,}454$ into $\purpleD{800}$ fives.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{5}&\overline{\Big)4{,}454}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{4{,}000}}&\purpleD{800}&\maroonD{5} \times \purpleD{800} = \blueE{4{,}000}\\ &454 \end{array}$  We have $454$ left.

Let's divide $454$ into $\purpleD{80}$ more fives.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{5}&\overline{\Big)4{,}454}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{4{,}000}&800\\ &454\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{400}}&\purpleD{80}&\maroonD{5} \times \purpleD{80} = \blueE{400}\\ &54\\ \end{array}$  We have $54$ left.

Let's divide $54$ into $\purpleD{10}$ more fives.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{5}&\overline{\Big)4{,}454}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{4{,}000}&800\\ &454\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{400}&80\\ &54\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{50}}&\purpleD{10}&\maroonD{5} \times \purpleD{10} = \blueE{50}\\ &4 \end{array}$  We have $4$ left. That is less than $5$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {5}&\overline{\Big)4{,}454}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{4{,}000}&\purpleD{800}\\ &454\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{400}&\purpleD{80}\\ &54\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{50}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{10}}\\ &\goldE{4}&\greenE{890} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{800} + \purpleD{80} + \purpleD{10}= \greenE{890}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{4}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{890}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{4}\\ 5\overline{\Big)4{,}454}& \end{align}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $3$ that may be useful:  - $3 \times 3 = 9$ - $3 \times 5 = 15$ - $3 \times 8 = 24$
What multiple of $3$ is less than $416$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {3}&\overline{\Big)416} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $416$ into $\purpleD{100}$ threes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{3}&\overline{\Big)416}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{300}}&\purpleD{100}&\maroonD{3} \times \purpleD{100} = \blueE{300}\\ &116 \end{array}$  We have $116$ left.

Let's divide $116$ into $\purpleD{30}$ more threes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{3}&\overline{\Big)416}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{300}&100\\ &116\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{90}}&\purpleD{30}&\maroonD{3} \times \purpleD{30} = \blueE{90}\\ &26 \end{array}$  We have $26$ left.

Let's divide $26$ into $\purpleD{8}$ more threes.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{3}&\overline{\Big)416}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{300}&100\\ &116\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{90}&30\\ &26\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{24}}&\purpleD{8}&\maroonD{3} \times \purpleD{8} = \blueE{24}\\ &2 \end{array}$  We have $2$ left. That is less than $3$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {3}&\overline{\Big)416}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{300}&\purpleD{100}\\ &116\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{90}&\purpleD{30}\\ &26\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{24}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{8}}\\ &\goldE{2}&\greenE{138} \end{array}$  $\purpleE{100} + \purpleE{30} + \purpleE{8}= \greenE{138}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{2}$.
$416\div3=\greenE{138}$ remainder $\goldE{2}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $5$ that may be useful:  - $5 \times 2 = 10$ - $5 \times 4 = 20$ - $5 \times 8 = 40$
What multiple of $5$ is less than $123$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {5}&\overline{\Big)123} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $123$ into $\purpleD{20}$ fives.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{5}&\overline{\Big)123}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{100}}&\purpleD{20}&\maroonD{5} \times \purpleD{20} = \blueE{100}\\ &23\\ \end{array}$  We have $23$ left.

Let's divide $23$ into $\purpleD{4}$ more fives.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{5}&\overline{\Big)123}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{100}&20\\ &23\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{20}}&\purpleD{4}&\maroonD{5} \times \purpleD{4} = \blueE{20}\\ &3 \end{array}$  We have $3$ left. That is less than $5$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {5}&\overline{\Big)123}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{100}&\purpleD{20}\\ &23\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{20}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{4}}\\ &\goldE{3}&\greenE{24}\\ \end{array}$  $\purpleD{20} + \purpleD{4}= \greenE{24}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{3}$.
$123\div5=\greenE{24}$ remainder $\goldE{3}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $4$ that may be useful:  - $4 \times 2 = 8$ - $4 \times 5 = 20$ - $4 \times 9 = 36$
What multiple of $4$ is less than $3{,}874$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {4}&\overline{\Big)3{,}874} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $3{,}874$ into $\purpleD{900}$ fours.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{4}&\overline{\Big)3{,}874}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{3{,}600}}&\purpleD{900}&\maroonD{4} \times \purpleD{900} = \blueE{3{,}600}\\ &274\\ \end{array}$  We have $274$ left.

Let's divide $274$ into $\purpleD{50}$ more fours.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{4}&\overline{\Big)3{,}874}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{3{,}600}&900\\ &274\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{200}}&\purpleD{50}&\maroonD{4} \times \purpleD{50} = \blueE{200}\\ &74 \end{array}$  We have $74$ left.

Let's divide $74$ into $\purpleD{10}$ more fours.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{4}&\overline{\Big)3{,}874}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{3{,}600}&900\\ &274\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{200}&50\\ &74\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{40}}&\purpleD{10}&\maroonD{4} \times \purpleD{10} = \blueE{40}\\ &34 \end{array}$  We have $34$ left.

Let's divide $34$ into $\purpleD{8}$ more fours because $8\times 4=32$.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{4}&\overline{\Big)3{,}874}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{3{,}600}&900\\ &274\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{200}&50\\ &74\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{40}&10\\ &34\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{32}}&\purpleD{8}&\maroonD{4} \times \purpleD{8} = \blueE{32}\\ &2 \end{array}$  We have $2$ left. That is less than $4$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {4}&\overline{\Big)3{,}874}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{3{,}600}&\purpleD{900}\\ &274\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{200}&\purpleD{50}\\ &74\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{40}&\purpleD{10}\\ &34\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{32}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{8}}\\ &\goldE{2}&\greenE{968} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{900} + \purpleD{50} + \purpleD{10} + \purpleD{8}= \greenE{968}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{2}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{968}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{2}\\ 4\overline{\Big)3{,}874}& \end{align}$

To divide larger numbers, we can split them into smaller numbers that we already know how to divide.  Let's think of a few multiples of $2$ that may be useful:  - $2 \times 3 = 6$ - $2 \times 5 = 10$ - $2 \times 8 = 16$
What multiple of $2$ is less than $2{,}367$?  $\begin{array}{rr} {2}&\overline{\Big)2{,}367} \end{array}$

Let's start by dividing $2{,}367$ into $\purpleD{1{,}000}$ twos.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{2}&\overline{\Big)2{,}367}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{2{,}000}}&\purpleD{1{,}000}&\maroonD{2} \times \purpleD{1{,}000} = \blueE{2{,}000}\\ &367 \end{array}$  We have $367$ left.

Let's divide $367$ into $\purpleD{100}$ more twos.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{2}&\overline{\Big)2{,}367}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}000}&1{,}000\\ &367\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{200}}&\purpleD{100}&\maroonD{2} \times \purpleD{100} = \blueE{200}\\ &167 \end{array}$  We have $167$ left.

Let's divide $167$ into $\purpleD{80}$ more twos.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{2}&\overline{\Big)2{,}367}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}000}&1{,}000\\ &367\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{200}&100\\ &167\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{160}}&\purpleD{80}&\maroonD{2} \times \purpleD{80} = \blueE{160}\\ &7 \end{array}$  We have $7$ left.

Let's divide $7$ into $\purpleD{3}$ more twos.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} \maroonD{2}&\overline{\Big)2{,}367}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}000}&1{,}000\\ &367\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{200}&100\\ &167\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{160}&80\\ &7\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueE{6}}&\purpleD{3}&\maroonD{2} \times \purpleD{3} = \blueE{6}\\ &1\\ \end{array}$  We have $1$ left. That is less than $2$, so we'll stop dividing.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Now, let's add all of the partial quotients to find our total quotient.   $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {2}&\overline{\Big)2{,}367}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{2{,}000}&\purpleD{1{,}000}\\ &367\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{200}&\purpleD{100}\\ &167\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{160}&\purpleD{80}\\ &7\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{6}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{3}}\\ &\goldE{1}&\greenE{1{,}183} \end{array}$  $\purpleD{1{,}000} + \purpleD{100} + \purpleD{80} + \purpleD{3}= \greenE{1{,}183}$. There is a remainder of $\goldE{1}$.
$\begin{align} \greenE{1{,}183}&\text{ remainder }\goldE{1}\\ 2\overline{\Big)2{,}367}& \end{align}$
